author: @cmjornal
title: Rapper impedida de entrar em Uber por causa do excesso de peso
text:
Motorista recusou-se a transport√°-la, desculpando-se que o carro tinha os "pneus em baixo".
Vanessa Fidalgo
Jornalista1 / 2
A rapper norte-americana Dank Demoss processou a Lyft, empresa de transporte individual de passageiros em ve√≠culo descaracterizado, depois de um motorista ter recusado transport√°-la devido ao seu peso.
A artista gravou a caricata conversa que teve com o motorista e fez quest√£o de partilhar o v√≠deo nas redes sociais, onde se ouve o homem a pedir desculpa e a dizer que n√£o a vai deixar entrar, recomendando-lhe que pe√ßa "um carro maior".
Depois, a rapper insiste, diz que cabe no ve√≠culo e o motorista diz que "tem os pneus vazios".
"E o que √© que eu tenho que ver com isso?", questiona Dank Demoss. "N√£o tenho espa√ßo atr√°s", insiste o motorista, pedindo desculpa.

author: Submitted by Ann Sterling
title: Barrington High graduates join forces to host lifesaving blood drive
text: Barrington High graduates join forces to host lifesaving blood drive In a powerful testament to the strength of community, two Barrington High School students ‚Äî Carter Bailey and Max Lewis ‚Äî are joining forces to fight for a cause that saved their lives: blood donation. Although separated by 10 years, their shared experiences with life-threatening illnesses have brought them together for a mission that is now close to their hearts. The duo is working to raise awareness about the importance of blood donation. In 2014, Carter Bailey was a senior at Barrington High School and cocaptain of the lacrosse team. But everything changed when he was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), a fast-growing cancer of the blood and bone marrow. ‚ÄúHe was a senior in high school and missed his entire lacrosse season,‚Äù said Celeste Bailey, Carter‚Äôs mom. ‚ÄúHis world was turned upside down as he faced the uncertainty of survival.‚Äù Throughout his treatment, Carter depended on numerous blood and platelet transfusions. ‚ÄúI have now been cancer free for over 10 years. Recognizing the growing need for blood and platelet donations as someone who has been on the receiving end, my family and I continue to organize a blood drive,‚Äù said Carter Bailey Max Lewis was diagnosed with aplastic anemia, a rare condition where the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells. He was just 11 years old. Throughout his treatment, which included a lifesaving stem cell transplant, Max underwent at least 10 blood transfusions ‚Äî critical to his survival. ‚ÄúWe never knew where the blood came from, but it was always there when Max needed it,‚Äù said Lisa Lewis, Max‚Äôs mother. ‚ÄúThe generosity of those anonymous donors saved his life, and that‚Äôs why we‚Äôre so passionate about this blood drive.‚Äù The Lewis family continues to host the annual blood drive as a way to give back to the community. ‚ÄúWhen Max was first diagnosed, so many friends, family, and neighbors asked, ‚ÄòHow can we help?‚Äô Now, we tell them, ‚ÄòYou can help by donating blood. You can help other kids in the same way Max was helped. Be a repeat customer, because there‚Äôs always a need.‚Äù What started as a fight for survival has grown into a mission of giving back. Carter and Max‚Äôs united vision to help others serves as a powerful reminder of the constant need for blood donations and the priceless lives donations save. The Carter Strong & Max‚Äôs Mission Vitalant Blood Drive will take place from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. on Saturday, Nov. 23, at Countryside Fire Station, 2222 N. Pepper Road, Lake Barrington. Walk-ins welcome. Visit [vitalant.org](https://www.vitalant.org) and search group code ORD0384D or call (877) 258-4825 to schedule your appointment. [terms of service](/info/terms-of-service/#conduct), click the "flag" link in the lower-right corner of the comment box. To find our more, read our [FAQ](/info/comments/).

author: Kent Lawlor
title: Northern Lights in Oldham: Some of your best pictures
text:
The Northern Lights made a stunning appearance across the UK last night (Thursday, October 10), lighting up the sky and dazzling sky watchers in Oldham.
The aurora borealis are usually influenced by geomagnetic storms which originate from activity on the Sun.
The phenomenon meant that Oldhamers were able to get an amazing sight of the stunning display, and people in the borough shared some amazing pictures they took.
Martin Robinson captured this impressive snap at the top of the moors in Oldham.
(Image: Martin Robinson)
Meanwhile, Karen Richards shared these pictures that were taken in Moorside.
From Moorside too pic.twitter.com/cohis05byh
‚Äî üå±Karen Richards ü™ê (@kreacher37) October 11, 2024 Tom Nokes captured these remarkable images of the Oldham sky lit up in red, green and blue.
Absolutely amazing!! Taken by me over Oldham tonight! @ChadWeather @BBCNWT @GranadaReports pic.twitter.com/sY0aJcgk1u
‚Äî Tom Nokes (@TomNokes) October 10, 2024 According to the BBC, the northern lights could be seen after an extremely geomagnetic storm - G5 - which is the highest on the one to five scale.
The BBC also said aurora might be visible in parts of the North again tonight, but are less likely in other parts of the country, so make sure to keep an eye out.
Northern Lights Nature

author: AFP
title: NYC protesters for Gaza ceasefire hold mock funeral - Breitbart
text: Hundreds of pro-Palestinian protesters took to the streets of New York on Thursday, staging a mock funeral in a demonstration against Israel‚Äôs continued heavy bombardement of the besieged Gaza strip. Holding banners demanding an immediate ceasefire, the activists gathered in Manhattan‚Äôs Bryant Park while some briefly stood in the middle of the busy Sixth Avenue in the heart of New York‚Äôs Midtown district. Several women shrouded in black held baby dolls swaddled in white cloths to represent the toll the fighting has taken on children in the coastal territory. The mock funeral procession headed to New York‚Äôs iconic Times Square where the protest continued with giant electronic advertisements as a backdrop. ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs action is to draw attention to the fact that, as of now, almost 10,000 children, just children alone, not counting everybody, not counting all Palestinians, have been killed‚Ä¶ in Gaza,‚Äù said archivist Grace Lile, 64. The war, which started with Hamas‚Äôs October 7 attack on Israel, has devastated much of northern Gaza, and the bombardment and fighting has intensified especially in the southern city of Khan Yunis. Israel has vowed to destroy Hamas in retaliation for the October 7 attack, which left about 1,140 people dead, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures. Israel‚Äôs relentless aerial bombardment and ground invasion have killed at least 21,320 people, mostly women and children, according to Hamas-run Gaza‚Äôs health ministry. New York City has seen dozens of protests since the October 7 attack and Israel‚Äôs military response, with both pro-Palestinian and pro-Israel demonstrators taking to the streets.
